title: Poll: GOP faith in party's plan for Syria drops
text:
Republicans’ confidence in their party’s plan for Syria has dropped in the aftermath of President Trump Donald John TrumpCharles Barkley: 'Vice President Pence needs to shut the hell up' Democrats say whistleblower deposition no longer central to impeachment investigation: report Trump plans to appeal House subpoena for financial records to Supreme Court MORE’s decision to withdraw troops from the northeastern part of the country, according to a new Reuters/Ipsos poll released Friday.

Fifty-four percent of Republicans surveyed said their party has a better plan for Syria than Democrats, independents or others for dealing with Syria, a 12-point drop from the same poll in April.

ADVERTISEMENT

Republicans’ confidence in the GOP’s strategy in combating terrorism has also taken a hit, with 65 percent saying their party had the better plan for managing the “War on Terror,” a drop of 10 points from six months ago.

Terry Brien, a GOP data manager who conducted the poll, told Reuters Trump’s withdrawal from northeastern Syria was “one of the biggest mistakes that we’ve made in a very long time” in the Middle East.

“Trump just seems to be out of his depth and out of touch on everything,” Brien said.

The Reuters/Ipsos poll comes a day after a CNN poll found that 75 percent of Americans are concerned about the ongoing situation in northeastern Syria, with many saying they fear an ISIS revival is likely.

Trump’s decision this month to withdraw troops from northeastern Syria in anticipation of a Turkish offensive caught Washington by surprise, with bipartisan critics saying the retreat green-lit the incursion and abandoned U.S.-aligned groups that had helped fight to defeat ISIS.

Reports surfaced that scores of Kurds were killed in the offensive and that some ISIS prisoners were able to escape as their Kurdish captors were forced to reallocate resources to defending themselves against Turkey.

Trump has defended the withdrawal, saying he campaigned on stopping “endless wars” and clarifying Wednesday that he will keep a “small number” of troops in Syria. The president also announced that Ankara decided to make permanent a cease-fire that forced Kurds in the area to withdraw from a designated safe zone along the Turkey-Syria border.

The Reuters/Ipsos poll surveyed 1,542 Republicans from Oct. 18-22 and has a credibility interval of plus or minus 2.8 percent.
description: Republicans’ confidence in their party’s plan for Syria has dropped in the aftermath of President Trump’s decision to withdraw troops from the northeastern part of the country, according to a new Reuters/Ipsos poll released Friday.
